One of the best games I've ever played.
Half-Life 2 was way ahead of its time in terms of storytelling and game mechanics. It was packed full of action, and it delivered a memorable story with distinct characters.

This game is a classic, where do I even begin: I got into playing HL2 late unlike true veterans of this franchise but boy do feel the same. Valve truly was ahead of their time creating this game in 2004, as people would say, this is grandfather of first person shooters. HL2 has some incredibly lovable characters: ranging from the badass Alyx Vance, the simple yet lovable D.O.G to the infamous dictator Wallace Breen - all so well wriiten and memorable.
The atmosphere in this game keeps you invested: from the simple wind blowing in the background as you traverse the coastline, keeping you on edge in Ravenholm to climbing across the bridge whilst gunning down combine soldier.
Some of the soundtracks in this game are so unique and unforgettable such: 'Triage At Dawn' being a personal favourite of mine.
The story is fantastically written as you are the physicist: Gordon Freeman surviving and rising up against the Combine, an extraterrestrial race that uses organic life as well as cybernetic enhancements to create their engines of war and destruction in this post apocalyptic dystopia. Using weapons, vehicles and unique puzzle solving you become a symbol of hope to the people; leading to the human uprising against the Combine.

Although the graphics are dated, this game still holds up as an instant classic and is worth your time and money. Especially considering how cheap this masterpiece is!

Well--when you're talking about a game that has 97,227(and counting) overwhelmingly positive reviews, you're not going to be able to say much of anything that hasn't already been said. It's an absolute masterpiece of a game in every aspect.  But to me, the number one key quality that makes Half Life 2 so amazing is the world-building. I'm talking in terms of all the various environments and settings in the game. Everything pulls you in and makes you feel like you really are on a journey; you're truly engaged in a process of discovery and adventure. This will maybe sound kind of crazy and out of place but I've often reflected that the world of Half Life 2 is sort of like a Dr. Suess book. I'm talking about the way the game grips your mind. Nobody ever forgets the experience of reading The Lorax or The Sleep Book or Horton Hears a Who. Those stories and those worlds literally embed themselves in your mind. And Half Life 2 does the same thing, as does Portal 2. I suppose in a roundabout way I'm just re-phrasing the well worn cliche, "It's like the game has a soul"...but as everyone knows, that's generally why cliches are cliches: there's so much truth in them. At any rate, I had to drop my two cents here because this is without a doubt one of the four or five best games of all time. Just paying homage, as it were. To anyone who hasn't played it yet, buy it immediately and enjoy every minute of it. I'm envious, because there's nothing like playing it through for the first time!:-)

A masterpiece that can rival modern FPS. Half-Life 2 is a science-fiction FPS set twenty years after the fisrt Half-Life. After the incidents in Half-Life 1, a alien race, the Combine, conquers the Earth, putting a kind of dictatorship on the planet. The game begins when the protagonist, Gordon Freeman, is awakened by a mysterious man, G-man, on a train heading to city 17. Then, we walk through the city and get to know some elements of the game. Not long after we are approached by Barney Calhoun, a resistance soldier who was a security-guard in the first game, and from there we are introduced to the resistance. And from here on, our goal is to help the resistance. During the game, various  characters are introduced to us, some from the first game, others completely new, like Alyx Vance (another member of the resistance and great friend of Gordon) and her hulk-style robot, Dog. Like any other FPS, we have a variety of guns, like pistols, machine guns, rocket launcher, etc, but in this game we have the famous gravity gun, a gun/machine that allows the player to pick up objects of any type either to throw them or to collect them or simply destroy them. During the game we will also find some vehicles such as boats and cars, some with weapons. The variety of enemies in the game is huge, we have the classic enemies from the first game, like the headcrab, the Combine soldiers and their machines and ships, like the striders, very similar to the Tripods from "War of the Worlds". The game environment is very beautiful, from cities to rural areas. The soundtrack is very similar to the first game, having songs that match comes with every situation. As in the first game, this one also has several puzzles, in which many of them we must use the gravity gun. In the end, despite being a somewhat old game, Half-Life 2 remains a great game with a story and captivating characters, with a gameplay that is even better than any other modern games. This game deserves a 10/10.

Rise and shine, Mister Freeman - rise and... shine. Not that I wish... to imply that you have been sleeping on... the job. No one is more deserving of a rest, and all the effort in the world would have gone to waste until... well... let's just say your hour has... come again. The right man in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world. So, wake up, Mister Freeman... wake up and... smell the ashes.

One of the greatest nostalgia trips

The FitnessGram PACER Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The test is used to measure a student's aerobic capacity as part of the FitnessGram assessment. Students run back and forth as many times as they can, each lap signaled by a beep sound.

I'm a huge fan of HL, I play it often and still love it. On the other hand, I know I played HL2 back in the day, but I can't seem to remember anything but throwing people with gravity gun. So, I bought it here on steam to play it again.... And there is a reason I don't remember details about this game - it is not that memorable. Basically you listen to dialogue, then you run and shoot enemies that spawn everywhere, and repeat. It's super linear and boring - you can't choose tactics you like (i.e. sneak, or avoid enemies). Bottom line, it is more Serious Sam than HL....
